Award.AwardTitle: Mathematics Research and Mentoring Program (Math RaMP)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematics Research and Mentoring Program (Math RaMP)
Spelman College

The Department of Mathematics at Spelman College has structured a comprehensive program: Mathematics Research and Mentoring Program (Math RaMP). The two main components of Math RaMP are the Scholarship Program and the Teaching Fellowship Program. The Math RaMP Scholars Program will prepare and direct talented students of color to mathematics graduate education and to careers in the mathematical sciences. Students who have demonstrated high potential and interest in mathematics through their achievement during the first-year and/or second year of college will be selected as RaMP Scholars to participate in a structured enrichment and support program. RaMP Scholars will be awarded academic scholarships that will require participation in the Journal Club Seminar as well as independent research in the mathematical sciences. The Math RaMP Teaching Fellowship Program will award a fellowship to a master?s level woman of color who is transitioning into a doctoral program. The RaMP Teaching Fellow will be mentored by faculty in the department and will gain experience in teaching college-level math. The Fellow will contribute to the Scholars Program by providing supplemental instruction for upper level mathematics courses. The objectives of Math RaMP are to mentor women of color and provide experiences to undergraduate students and a master?s level student that would contribute to the academic success of both groups and assist in increasing the pipeline of women of color pursuing advanced degrees in the mathematical sciences.

The Mathematics Research and Mentoring Program (Math RaMP) addresses many of the critical issues and challenges facing African American women at the undergraduate level in mathematics while also preparing and inspiring women of color to continue to graduate study in the mathematical sciences and to associated careers. Overcoming some of the challenges involve: meeting financial needs, building self-confidence, providing role models and mentors, promoting a sense of belonging in science and mathematics for the under-represented, and providing a challenging yet supportive academic environment within a nurturing community?one which expresses high expectations and confidence in the ability of students to achieve. The overall goal of the proposed program is to increase the number of African American women who pursue advanced degrees or careers in the mathematical sciences with an enhanced understanding of the broader career options available in pure and applied mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recruitment and retention of African-American women in undergraduate mathematics require attention to special challenges faced by these students - challenges that result from social and economic factors and the nature of their prior education. Overcoming some of the challenges involves meeting financial needs, building self-confidence, providing role models and mentors, promoting a sense of belonging in science and mathematics for the under-represented, and providing a challenging yet supportive academic environment within a nurturing community - one which expresses high expectations and confidence in the ability of students to achieve.

The purpose of the Mathematics Research and Mentoring Program (Math RaMP) was to address some of these critical issues and challenges, while also preparing and inspiring women studying mathematics at Spelman College to continue on to graduate study and careers in the mathematical sciences. The two components of Math RaMP were the Scholars Program and the Teaching Fellowship Program. The main objectives of the Scholars Program were to provide scholarships, provide mentoring through research with a faculty member, and to create a nurturing community supportive of student development. Objectives of the Teaching Fellowship program were to give a woman of color transitioning form a master's degree to a doctorate degree the opportunity to gain experience in college-level instruction, and the opportunity to be mentored by a faculty to become a future faculty member.

Spelman mathematics majors at the sophomore level or above who demonstrated high potential and interest in mathematics were selected as Math RaMP scholars. An average of 16 scholars received scholarships each semester during the first three years of the program and 10 scholars received scholarships each semester in the last year of the program. A journal club for sophomore scholars, peer-mentoring meetings, graduate school preparation workshops, and panel discussions with Spelman mathematics graduates currently in graduate school were some important activities of the program which gave scholars the opportunity to build a supportive and nurturing community network. Junior and senior scholars conducted year-long research projects with Spelman faculty and gave oral presentations of their work at Spelman's annual Research Day. Several scholars also presented their work at local and national conferences. In order to give scholars the opportunity to see how mathematics is applied to real-world problems and to motivate them to pursue graduate degrees and/or careers in the mathematical sciences, all scholars were required to participate in a summer research experience or internship at the end of their sophomore and junior years.

As one of the major goals of Math RaMP was to increase the number of African-American women who pursue advanced degrees in the mathematical sciences, all senior scholars were required to apply to graduate programs. Some of the graduate programs that Math RaMP scholars were accepted into and are currently enrolled in are University of Maryland, College Park (Ph.D. Mathematics, Ph.D. Applied Mathematics), North Carolina State University (Ph.D. Statistics, Ph.D. Operations Research), Louisiana State University (Ph.D. Mathematics), University of Louisiana (M.S. Mathematics), University of Michigan (M.S. Applied Mathematics), and Emory University (M.S. Public Health).
